description: Middle French dixme, Old French disme (“tenth, tithe”), from Latin decimus (“tenth”). Doublet of dime.

entries.meaning: (US, dated, 18th century) A dime minted in 1792.
(obsolete) A tenth; a tenth part; a tithe.
examples: The pope began to exercise his new rapines by a compliance with king Edward, in granting him two years’ disme from the clergy.
